standard_metadata.standard_description: Apply properties of operations as strategies to add, subtract, factor, and expand linear expressions with rational coefficients.

hints.content: Let's use the distributive property to expand each expression and see if it is equivalent to $-90-60w$.

##Expression: ${-30}(3+2w)$  Let's distribute the $\blueD{-30}$ to each of the terms inside of the parentheses.   $\begin{align}\blueD{-30}(3+2w)&\stackrel{?}=-90-60w\\ \\ (\blueD{-30}\times3)+(\blueD{-30}\times2w)&\stackrel{?}=-90-60w\\ \\ -90+(-60w)&\stackrel{?}=-90-60w\\ \\-90-60w&\stackrel{\checkmark}=-90-60w\end{align}$  Yes, ${-30}(3+2w)$ is equivalent to $-90-60w$.

##Expression: $(-9-6w)\cdot10$  Let's distribute the $\blueD{10}$ to each of the terms inside of the parentheses.   $\begin{align}(-9-6w)\cdot\blueD{10}&\stackrel{?}=-90-60w\\ \\\blueD{10}(-9-6w)&\stackrel{?}=-90-60w\\ \\ (\blueD{10}\times-9)+(\blueD{10}\times-6w)&\stackrel{?}=-90-60w\\ \\ -90+(-60w)&\stackrel{?}=-90-60w\\ \\-90-60w&\stackrel{\checkmark}=-90-60w\end{align}$   Yes, $(-9-6w)\cdot10$ is equivalent to $-90-60w$.

##Expression: $-3(30-20w)$  Let's distribute the $\blueD{-3}$ to each of the terms inside of the parentheses.   $\begin{align}\blueD{-3}(30-20w)&\stackrel{?}=-90-60w\\ \\ (\blueD{-3}\times30)+(\blueD{-3}\times-20w)&\stackrel{?}=-90-60w\\ \\-90+60w&\neq-90-60w\end{align}$   No, $-3(30-20w)$ is **not** equivalent to $-90-60w$.

##Expression: $(6+4w)\times15$   Let's distribute the $\blueD{15}$ to each of the terms inside of the parentheses.   $\begin{align}(6+4w)\times\blueD{15}&\stackrel{?}=-90-60w\\ \\\blueD{15}(6+4w)&\stackrel{?}=-90-60w\\ \\ (\blueD{15}\times6)+(\blueD{15}\times4w)&\stackrel{?}=-90-60w\\ \\90+60w&\neq-90-60w\end{align}$   No, $(6+4w)\times15$ is **not** equivalent to $-90-60w$.

##Expression: $-20(4.5+3w)$  Let's distribute the $\blueD{-20}$ to each of the terms inside of the parentheses.   $\begin{align}\blueD{-20}(4.5+3w)&\stackrel{?}=-90-60w\\ \\ (\blueD{-20}\times4.5)+(\blueD{-20}\times3w)&\stackrel{?}=-90-60w\\ \\ -90+(-60w)&\stackrel{?}=-90-60w\\ \\-90-60w&\stackrel{\checkmark}=-90-60w\end{align}$   Yes, $-20(4.5+3w)$ is equivalent to $-90-60w$.
The following expressions are equivalent to $-90-60w$:   - ${-30}(3+2w)$ -  $(-9-6w)\cdot10$ - $-20(4.5+3w)$
Let's use the distributive property to expand each expression and see if it is equivalent to $10a-25+5b$.

##Expression: $(2a-5+b)5$  Let's distribute the $\blueD{5}$ to each of the terms inside of the parentheses.   $\begin{align} (2a-5+b)\blueD{5}&\stackrel{?}=10a-25+5b\\\\ \blueD{5}(2a-5+b)&\stackrel{?}=10a-25+5b\\\\ (\blueD{5}\times2a)+(\blueD{5}\times-5)+(\blueD{5}\times b)&\stackrel{?}=10a-25+5b\\\\ 10a+(-25)+5b&\stackrel{?}=10a-25+5b\\\\ 10a-25+5b&\stackrel{\checkmark}{=}10a-25+5b\end{align}$  Yes, $(2a-5+b)5$ is equivalent to $10a-25+5b$.

##Expression: $-2(-5a-25+5b)$  Let's distribute the $\blueD{-2}$ to each of the terms inside of the parentheses.   $\begin{align} \blueD{-2}(-5a-25+5b)&\stackrel{?}=10a-25+5b\\\\ (\blueD{-2}\times-5a)+(\blueD{-2}\times-25)+(\blueD{-2}\times5b)&\stackrel{?}=10a-25+5b\\\\ 10a+50+(-10b)&\stackrel{?}=10a-25+5b\\\\ 10a+50-10b&\neq 10a-25+5b\end{align}$  No, $-2(-5a-25+5b)$ is **not** equivalent to $10a-25+5b$.

##Expression: $10\times(a-2.5+0.5b)$  Let's distribute the $\blueD{10}$ to each of the terms inside of the parentheses.   $\begin{align} \blueD{10}\times(a-2.5+0.5b)&\stackrel{?}=10a-25+5b\\\\ (\blueD{10}\times a)+(\blueD{10}\times-2.5)+(\blueD{10}\times0.5b)&\stackrel{?}=10a-25+5b\\\\ 10a+(-25)+5b&\stackrel{?}=10a-25+5b\\\\ 10a-25+5b&\stackrel{\checkmark}{=} 10a-25+5b\end{align}$  Yes, $10\times(a-2.5+0.5b)$ is equivalent to $10a-25+5b$.

##Expression: $(-2a+5-b)\cdot(-5)$  Let's distribute the $\blueD{-5}$ to each of the terms inside of the parentheses.   $\begin{align} (-2a+5-b)\cdot(\blueD{-5})&\stackrel{?}=10a-25+5b\\\\ \blueD{-5}(-2a+5-b)&\stackrel{?}=10a-25+5b\\\\ (\blueD{-5}\times-2a)+(\blueD{-5}\times5)+(\blueD{-5}\times-b)&\stackrel{?}=10a-25+5b\\\\ 10a+(-25)+5b&\stackrel{?}=10a-25+5b\\\\ 10a-25+5b&\stackrel{\checkmark}{=} 10a-25+5b\end{align}$  Yes, $(-2a+5-b)\cdot(-5)$ is equivalent to $10a-25+5b$.

##Expression: $-10\cdot(-a-2.5-b)$  Let's distribute the $\blueD{-10}$ to each of the terms inside of the parentheses.   $\begin{align} \blueD{-10}\cdot(-a-2.5-b)&\stackrel{?}=10a-25+5b\\\\ (\blueD{-10}\times-a)+(\blueD{-10}\times-2.5)+(\blueD{-10}\times-b)&\stackrel{?}=10a-25+5b\\\\ 10a+25+5b&\neq 10a-25+5b\end{align}$  No, $-10\cdot(-a-2.5-b)$ is **not** equivalent to $10a-25+5b$.
The following expressions are equivalent to $10a-25+5b$:   - $(2a-5+b)5$ - $10\times(a-2.5+0.5b)$ - $(-2a+5-b)\cdot(-5)$
Let's use the distributive property to expand each expression and see if it is equivalent to $22c+33d$.

##Expression: $(-2c-3d)(-11)$  Let's distribute the $\blueD{-11}$ to each of the terms inside of the parentheses.   $\begin{align} (-2c-3d)(\blueD{-11})&\stackrel{?}=22c+33d\\\\ \blueD{-11}(-2c-3d)&\stackrel{?}=22c+33d\\\\ (\blueD{-11}\times-2c)+(\blueD{-11}\times-3d)&\stackrel{?}=22c+33d\\\\ 22c+33d&\stackrel{\checkmark}{=} 22c+33d\end{align}$  Yes, $(-2c-3d)(-11)$ is equivalent to $22c+33d$.

##Expression: $2\left(11c-\dfrac{33}{2}d\right)$  Let's distribute the $\blueD{2}$ to each of the terms inside of the parentheses.   $\begin{align} \blueD{2}\left(11c-\dfrac{33}{2}d\right)&\stackrel{?}=22c+33d\\\\ (\blueD{2}\times11c)+\left(\blueD{2}\times-\dfrac{33}{2}d\right)&\stackrel{?}=22c+33d\\\\ 22c+(-33d)&\stackrel{?}=22c+33d\\\\ 22c-33d&\neq 22c+33d\end{align}$  No, $2\left(11c-\dfrac{33}{2}d\right)$ is **not** equivalent to $22c+33d$.

##Expression: $(66c+99d)\cdot\dfrac{1}{3}$  Let's distribute the $\blueD{\dfrac{1}{3}}$ to each of the terms inside of the parentheses.   $\begin{align} (66c+99d)\cdot\blueD{\dfrac{1}{3}}&\stackrel{?}=22c+33d\\\\ \blueD{\dfrac{1}{3}}(66c+99d)&\stackrel{?}=22c+33d\\\\ \left(\blueD{\dfrac{1}{3}}\times66c\right)+\left(\blueD{\dfrac{1}{3}}\times99d\right)&\stackrel{?}=22c+33d\\\\ 22c+33d&\stackrel{\checkmark}{=} 22c+33d\end{align}$  Yes, $(66c+99d)\cdot\dfrac{1}{3}$ is equivalent to $22c+33d$.

##Expression: $-1\times(-22-33d)$  Let's distribute the $\blueD{-1}$ to each of the terms inside of the parentheses.   $\begin{align} \blueD{-1}\times(-22-33d)&\stackrel{?}=22c+33d\\\\ (\blueD{-1}\times-22)+(\blueD{-1}\times-33d)&\stackrel{?}=22c+33d\\\\ 22+33d&\neq 22c+33d\end{align}$  No, $-1\times(-22-33d)$ is **not** equivalent to $22c+33d$.

##Expression: $11\cdot(2c+3d)$  Let's distribute the $\blueD{11}$ to each of the terms inside of the parentheses.   $\begin{align} \blueD{11}\cdot(2c+3d)&\stackrel{?}=22c+33d\\\\ (\blueD{11}\times2c)+(\blueD{11}\times3d)&\stackrel{?}=22c+33d\\\\ 22c+33d&\stackrel{\checkmark}{=} 22c+33d\end{align}$  Yes, $11\cdot(2c+3d)$ is equivalent to $22c+33d$.
The following expressions are equivalent to $22c+33d$:  - $(-2c-3d)(-11)$ - $(66c+99d)\cdot\dfrac{1}{3}$ - $11\cdot(2c+3d)$
Let's use the distributive property to expand each expression and see if it is equivalent to $-56z+28$.

##Expression: $\dfrac{1}{2}\cdot(-28z+14)$  Let's distribute the $\blueD{\dfrac{1}{2}}$ to each of the terms inside of the parentheses.   $\begin{align} \blueD{\dfrac{1}{2}}\cdot(-28z+14)&\stackrel{?}=-56z+28\\\\ \left(\blueD{\dfrac{1}{2}}\times-28z\right)+\left(\blueD{\dfrac{1}{2}}\times14\right)&\stackrel{?}=-56z+28\\\\ -14z+7&\neq -56z+28\end{align}$  No, $\dfrac{1}{2}\cdot(-28z+14)$ is **not** equivalent to $-56z+28$.

##Expression: $(-1.4z+0.7)\times40$  Let's distribute the $\blueD{40}$ to each of the terms inside of the parentheses.   $\begin{align} (-1.4z+0.7)\times\blueD{40}&\stackrel{?}=-56z+28\\\\ \blueD{40}(-1.4z+0.7)&\stackrel{?}=-56z+28\\\\ (\blueD{40}\times-1.4z)+(\blueD{40}\times0.7)&\stackrel{?}=-56z+28\\\\ -56z+28&\stackrel{\checkmark}{=} -56z+28\end{align}$  Yes, $(-1.4z+0.7)\times40$ is equivalent to $-56z+28$.

##Expression: $(14-7z)\cdot(-4)$  Let's distribute the $\blueD{-4}$ to each of the terms inside of the parentheses.   $\begin{align} (14-7z)\cdot(\blueD{-4})&\stackrel{?}=-56z+28\\\\ \blueD{-4}(14-7z)&\stackrel{?}=-56z+28\\\\ (\blueD{-4}\times14)+(\blueD{-4}\times-7z)&\stackrel{?}=-56z+28\\\\ -56+28z&\neq -56z+28\end{align}$  No, $(14-7z)\cdot(-4)$ is **not** equivalent to $-56z+28$.

##Expression: $(8z-4)(-7)$  Let's distribute the $\blueD{-7}$ to each of the terms inside of the parentheses.   $\begin{align} (8z-4)(\blueD{-7})&\stackrel{?}=-56z+28\\\\ \blueD{-7}(8z-4)&\stackrel{?}=-56z+28\\\\ (\blueD{-7}\times8z)+(\blueD{-7}\times-4)&\stackrel{?}=-56z+28\\\\ -56z+28&\stackrel{\checkmark}{=} -56z+28\end{align}$  Yes, $(8z-4)(-7)$ is equivalent to $-56z+28$.

##Expression: $-2(-28z-14)$  Let's distribute the $\blueD{-2}$ to each of the terms inside of the parentheses.   $\begin{align} \blueD{-2}(-28z-14)&\stackrel{?}=-56z+28\\\\ (\blueD{-2}\times-28z)+(\blueD{-2}\times-14)&\stackrel{?}=-56z+28\\\\ 56z+28&\neq -56z+28\end{align}$  No, $-2(-28z-14)$ is **not** equivalent to $-56z+28$.
The following expressions are equivalent to $-56z+28$:   - $(-1.4z+0.7)\times40$ - $(8z-4)(-7)$
Let's use the distributive property to expand each expression and see if it is equivalent to $6g-18h$.

##Expression: $(g-3)\cdot6$  Let's distribute the $\blueD{6}$ to each of the terms inside of the parentheses.   $\begin{align} (g-3)\cdot\blueD{6}&\stackrel{?}=6g-18h\\\\ \blueD{6}(g-3)&\stackrel{?}=6g-18h\\\\ (\blueD{6}\times g)+(\blueD{6}\times-3)&\stackrel{?}=6g-18h\\\\ 6g+(-18)&\stackrel{?}=6g-18h\\\\ 6g-18&\neq 6g-18h\end{align}$  No, $(g-3)\cdot6$ is **not** equivalent to $6g-18h$.

##Expression: $2\cdot(3g-18h)$  Let's distribute the $\blueD{2}$ to each of the terms inside of the parentheses.   $\begin{align} \blueD{2}\cdot(3g-18h)&\stackrel{?}=6g-18h\\\\ (\blueD{2}\times3g)+(\blueD{2}\times-18h)&\stackrel{?}=6g-18h\\\\ 6g+(-36h)&\stackrel{?}=6g-18h\\\\ 6g-36h&\neq 6g-18h\end{align}$  No, $2\cdot(3g-18h)$ is **not** equivalent to $6g-18h$.

##Expression: $3(2g-6h)$  Let's distribute the $\blueD{3}$ to each of the terms inside of the parentheses.   $\begin{align} \blueD{3}(2g-6h)&\stackrel{?}=6g-18h\\\\ (\blueD{3}\times2g)+(\blueD{3}\times-6h)&\stackrel{?}=6g-18h\\\\ 6g+(-18h)&\stackrel{?}=6g-18h\\\\ 6g-18h&\stackrel{\checkmark}{=} 6g-18h\end{align}$  Yes, $3(2g-6h)$ is equivalent to $6g-18h$.

##Expression: $(-g-3h)(-6)$  Let's distribute the $\blueD{-6}$ to each of the terms inside of the parentheses.   $\begin{align} (-g-3h)(\blueD{-6})&\stackrel{?}=6g-18h\\\\ \blueD{-6}(-g-3h)&\stackrel{?}=6g-18h\\\\ (\blueD{-6}\times-g)+(\blueD{-6}\times-3h)&\stackrel{?}=6g-18h\\\\ 6g+18h&\neq 6g-18h\end{align}$  No, $(-g-3h)(-6)$ is **not** equivalent to $6g-18h$.

##Expression: $-2\times(-3g+9h)$  Let's distribute the $\blueD{-2}$ to each of the terms inside of the parentheses.   $\begin{align} \blueD{-2}\times(-3g+9h)&\stackrel{?}=6g-18h\\\\ (\blueD{-2}\times-3g)+(\blueD{-2}\times9h)&\stackrel{?}=6g-18h\\\\ 6g+(-18h)&\stackrel{?}=6g-18h\\\\ 6g-18h&\stackrel{\checkmark}{=} 6g-18h\end{align}$  Yes, $-2\times(-3g+9h)$ is equivalent to $6g-18h$.
The following expressions are equivalent to $6g-18h$:  - $3(2g-6h)$ - $-2\times(-3g+9h)$
Let's use the distributive property to expand each expression and see if it is equivalent to $35+30s-45t$.

##Expression: $7\cdot(5+30s-45t)$  Let's distribute the $\blueD{7}$ to each of the terms inside of the parentheses.   $\begin{align} \blueD{7}\cdot(5+30s-45t)&\stackrel{?}=35+30s-45t\\\\ (\blueD{7}\times5)+(\blueD{7}\times30s)+(\blueD{7}\times-45t)&\stackrel{?}=35+30s-45t\\\\ 35+210s+(-315t)&\stackrel{?}=35+30s-45t\\\\ 35+210s-315t&\neq 35+30s-45t\end{align}$  No, $7\cdot(5+30s-45t)$ is **not** equivalent to $35+30s-45t$.

##Expression: $5(7+6s-9t)$  Let's distribute the $\blueD{5}$ to each of the terms inside of the parentheses.   $\begin{align} \blueD{5}(7+6s-9t)&\stackrel{?}=35+30s-45t\\\\ (\blueD{5}\times7)+(\blueD{5}\times6s)+(\blueD{5}\times-9t)&\stackrel{?}=35+30s-45t\\\\ 35+30s+(-45t)&\stackrel{?}=35+30s-45t\\\\ 35+30s-45t&\stackrel{\checkmark}{=} 35+30s-45t\end{align}$  Yes, $5(7+6s-9t)$ is equivalent to $35+30s-45t$.

##Expression: $(-35-30s+45t)\times(-1)$  Let's distribute the $\blueD{-1}$ to each of the terms inside of the parentheses.   $\begin{align} (-35-30s+45t)\times(\blueD{-1})&\stackrel{?}=35+30s-45t\\\\ \blueD{-1}(-35-30s+45t)&\stackrel{?}=35+30s-45t\\\\ (\blueD{-1}\times-35)+(\blueD{-1}\times-30s)+(\blueD{-1}\times45t)&\stackrel{?}=35+30s-45t\\\\ 35+30s+(-45t)&\stackrel{?}=35+30s-45t\\\\ 35+30s-45t&\stackrel{\checkmark}{=} 35+30s-45t\end{align}$  Yes, $(-35-30s+45t)\times(-1)$ is equivalent to $35+30s-45t$.

##Expression: $10\times(3.5+3s-4.5)$  Let's distribute the $\blueD{10}$ to each of the terms inside of the parentheses.   $\begin{align} \blueD{10}\times(3.5+3s-4.5)&\stackrel{?}=35+30s-45t\\\\ (\blueD{10}\times3.5)+(\blueD{10}\times3s)+(\blueD{10}\times-4.5)&\stackrel{?}=35+30s-45t\\\\ 35+30s+(-45)&\stackrel{?}=35+30s-45t\\\\ 35+30s-45&\neq 35+30s-45t\end{align}$  No, $10\times(3.5+3s-4.5)$ is **not** equivalent to $35+30s-45t$.

##Expression: $\left(\dfrac{35}{2}-15s+\dfrac{45}{2}t\right)\cdot(-2)$  Let's distribute the $\blueD{-2}$ to each of the terms inside of the parentheses.   $\begin{align} \left(\dfrac{35}{2}-15s+\dfrac{45}{2}t\right)\cdot(\blueD{-2})&\stackrel{?}=35+30s-45t\\\\ \blueD{-2}\left(\dfrac{35}{2}-15s+\dfrac{45}{2}t\right)&\stackrel{?}=35+30s-45t\\\\ \left(\blueD{-2}\times\dfrac{35}{2}\right)+(\blueD{-2}\times-15s)+\left(\blueD{-2}\times\dfrac{45}{2}t\right)&\stackrel{?}=35+30s-45t\\\\ -35+30s+(-45t)&\stackrel{?}=35+30s-45t\\\\ -35+30s-45t&\neq 35+30s-45t\end{align}$  No, $\left(\dfrac{35}{2}-15s+\dfrac{45}{2}t\right)\cdot(-2)$ is **not** equivalent to $35+30s-45t$.
The following expressions are equivalent to $35+30s-45t$:   - $5(7+6s-9t)$ - $(-35-30s+45t)\times(-1)$

question.content: **Apply the distributive property to create an equivalent expression.**  $\dfrac12\left(6e - 3f - \dfrac34\right) =$

hints.content: Let's distribute the $\blueE{\dfrac12}$ to each of the terms inside of the parentheses.

$\begin{align} &\phantom{=}\blueE{\dfrac12}\left(6e - 3f - \dfrac34\right)\\\\ &=\left(\blueE{\dfrac12}\cdot6e\right)+\left(\blueE{\dfrac12}\cdot(-3f)\right) + \left(\blueE{\dfrac12}\cdot\left(-\dfrac34\right)\right)\\ \\  &= 3e+\left(-\dfrac32f\right)+ \left(-\dfrac38\right) \\\\  &=3e-\dfrac32f-\dfrac38 \end{align}$
$\dfrac12\left(6e - 3f - \dfrac34\right)  =3e-\dfrac32f-\dfrac38 $

question.content: **Apply the distributive property to create an equivalent expression.**  $(m-3+4n)\cdot (-8) =$

hints.content: Let's distribute the $\blueD{-8}$ to each of the terms inside of the parentheses.

$\begin{align} &\phantom{=}(m-3+4n)\cdot (\blueD{-8})\\\\ &=\left(\blueD{-8}\cdot m\right)+\left(\blueD{-8}\cdot(-3)\right) + \left(\blueD{-8}\cdot\left(4n\right)\right)\\ \\  &= -8m+24+(-32n) \\\\  &=-8m+24-32n \end{align}$

question.content: **Apply the distributive property to create an equivalent expression.**  $(3-8y)\cdot(-2.5) =$

hints.content: Let's distribute the $\blueD{-2.5}$ to each of the terms inside of the parentheses.
$\begin{align}( 3-8y)\cdot(\blueD{-2.5})&=(\blueD{-2.5}\cdot3)+(\blueD{-2.5}\cdot-8y) \\\\  &= -7.5+20y\end{align}$

question.content: **Apply the distributive property to create an equivalent expression.**  $5\times(-2w-4) =$

hints.content: Let's distribute the $\blueD{5}$ to each of the terms inside of the parentheses.

question.content: **Apply the distributive property to create an equivalent expression.**  $-9\cdot(5j+k) =$

hints.content: Let's distribute the $\blueD{-9}$ to each of the terms inside of the parentheses.
$\begin{align} \blueD{-9}\cdot(5j+k)&=(\blueD{-9}\cdot5j)+(\blueD{-9}\cdot k) \\\\  &=-45j+(-9k)\\\\ &=-45j-9k \end{align}$

question.content: **Apply the distributive property to create an equivalent expression.**  $(-7c+8d)0.6 =$

hints.content: Let's distribute the $\blueD{0.6}$ to each of the terms inside of the parentheses.
$\begin{align} (-7c+8d)\blueD{0.6}&=(-7c\cdot \blueD{0.6})+(8d\cdot\blueD{0.6}) \\\\ &=-4.2c+4.8d \end{align}$
